14433.meaning_1: to kindle; to light; to set on fire
14433.meaning_lit: to cause to burn or blaze up
14433.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
ujjalayati is a causative verb meaning "to cause to burn" or "to light/fire". In the contextual sentence (sn7.9:13.2), the speaker declares "now I light only the inner flame", using the verb in first person singular present (ajjhattamevujjalayāmi). This reflects a metaphorical use, where inner spiritual illumination is likened to kindling a fire. The verb is causative of ujjaleti and shows irregular development from the root √jal with the causative suffix *aya, influenced by the prefix ud-.
14433.example_1: now I light only the inner flame.

28085.meaning_1: kindles; lights; sets fire (to); causes to burn
28085.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In SN7.9, the verb jalayati is used in the sense "I kindle a light within myself" (ajjhattameva jalayāmi jotiṃ), indicating the causative meaning "to cause to burn/shine" rather than simple burning. The form is irregular causative from √jal, showing the *aya suffix with subsequent phonetic development jālaya > jalaya.
28085.example_1:
hitvā ahaṃ brāhmaṇa dārudāhaṃajjhattamevujjalayāmi [ajjhattameva jalayāmi] jotiṃ,
arahaṃ ahaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carāmi.

36979.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
niccagginī is a compound adjective meaning "always blazing" or "ever-burning". In the context of SN 7.9:13.3, it describes a state of constant intensity or fervor, paired with niccasamāhita ("always serene"), suggesting a balanced yet powerful inner condition. The word combines nicca ("constant, eternal") with aggi ("fire"), forming a kammadhāraya compound. The feminine ending -ī agrees with an implied feminine noun such as "mind" or "state".

37002.meaning_1: constantly self-composed; always internally settled; forever inwardly focused
37002.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word niccasamāhitatta describes a state of continuous inner composure and collectedness. In the context of SN 7.9:13.3, it characterizes a person who is always "blazing" with spiritual ardor yet simultaneously "always serene" or self-composed. The compound combines nicca (constant, permanent) with samāhita (collected, composed) and atta (self), literally meaning "one whose self is constantly composed." This reflects a high level of meditative stability where the mind remains undisturbed regardless of external conditions.

35212.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.9:14.2, dhuma (smoke) is used metaphorically to represent anger, contrasting with bhasman (ashes) representing lies. This metaphor suggests that anger, like smoke, is a visible, rising, and transient manifestation of inner turmoil, while lies are the residual ashes left behind. The phonetic change ū > u is a regular Pāḷi sound shift from Sanskrit dhūma to Pāḷi dhuma.
35212.example_1: anger your smoke, and lies your ashes.

63702.meaning_1: name of Sakka’s wife, a titan maiden
63702.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
Sujā is the name of Sakka’s wife, described as an asurakaññā (titan maiden). The name is formed from the prefix su- “good, well” + the root √jan “to be born”, yielding the meaning “well-born” or “of good birth”. This etymology aligns with her high status as the consort of the devānamindo. The name explains the epithet sujampati “husband of Sujā”.
63702.sutta_1: sakkassa, bhikkhave, devānamindassa sujā nāma asurakaññā pajāpati, tasmā sujampatīti vuccati.
63702.example_1: Sakka’s wife is the titan maiden named Sujā. That’s why he’s called Sujampati, Sujā’s Husband.

63162.meaning_1: with banks of ethical conduct; shored by morality
63162.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The compound sīlatittha literally means "ethics as a ford" or "morality as a crossing place". In the contextual sentence from SN 7.9, the Buddha compares the Dhamma to a lake, with sīlatittha meaning that ethical conduct serves as the safe "banks" or "staircase" into the water. The image suggests that just as a tittha (ford, staircase to water) allows safe access to a lake, sīla (ethics) provides the proper and safe means of approach to the Dhamma. This is a beautiful metaphor illustrating how moral discipline is not a restriction but a supportive structure enabling one to enter and benefit from the deeper teachings.
63162.example_1: The teaching is a lake, brahmin, <j>into which ethics are the stairs,

3830.meaning_1: with a dry body; with dry limbs
3830.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word anallagatta means "with dry limbs" or "with a dry body". It is formed by adding the negative prefix an- to alla ("wet") and gatta ("limbs, body"). In the contextual sentence from SN 7.9:15.4, it describes those who cross to the far shore with dry limbs, symbolizing spiritual purity or freedom from defilements. This is a kammadhāraya compound where the negated quality (wetness) is attributed to the body.
3830.example_1: and cross to the far shore with dry limbs.

3831.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the Sundarikasutta (SN7.9), the term describes beings who cross over the flood of existence without being粘着 (stuck) to sensual pleasures or defilements. The metaphor of "body" (gatta) refers to the psycho-physical organism. "Without a sticky body" means free from clinging, attachment, and craving. The variant reading anallagattāva in the text is a metathesis of the more correct anallīnagattāva.
3831.example_1:
dhammo rahado brāhmaṇa sīlatittho,
anāvilo sabbhi sataṃ pasattho,
yattha have vedaguno sinātā,
anallagattāva [anallīnagattāva] taranti pāraṃ.

30962.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word tujjubhūta means "straight; upright; erect" and is formed by adding the prefix t- to ujju + bhūta. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.9:16.3, it describes those who are morally upright or straight in conduct, to whom homage should be paid. The phonetic note "+t (Kacc 35, 34)" indicates the addition of the t- prefix according to grammatical rules.
30962.example_1: pay homage to the upright ones.

48147.meaning_1: the Many-Questions Sutta; the discourse on many questions
48147.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the name of a well-known discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 7.10), where a brahmin poses numerous questions to the Buddha about various topics including the nature of the self, the world, and the path to liberation. The title literally means "the discourse on many questions" or "the many-questions sutta", indicating its thematic focus on a wide range of philosophical and practical inquiries.

1238.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term ajjasaṭṭhiṃ is an adverbial compound meaning "for the past six days" or "during the last six days including today". It is formed from ajja "today" and saṭṭhiṃ "six" in the accusative case, indicating duration of time. The contextual sentence from SN 7.10:2.3 uses this term to indicate that someone has been missing for the past six days, including the current day.
1238.example_1: missing for the past six days:

30835.grammar: ind, loc sg of tilākhettasmiṃ, comp, irreg
30835.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is an irregular locative singular form of the compound tilākhettasmiṃ "a field of sesame". The ending -smi represents the locative case, contracted from -smiṃ. The contextual sentence describes a sesame field that has been ruined, indicating agricultural destruction or misfortune affecting the crop.

33612.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word dupaṇṇa means "two-leaved" or "having two leaves", as seen in the contextual sentence from SN 7.10:3.3 where it is paired with ekapaṇṇā (one-leaved) to describe plants with either one or two leaves. It is formed by the combination of the prefix du- (two) and paṇṇa (leaf).
33612.example_1: with just one or two leaves:

34418.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The reading dvipaṇṇa is supported by the surrounding context ekapaṇṇā dupaṇṇā ca, showing a progression from one-leafed to two-leafed. The form appears in a verse describing various types of vegetation, indicating the Buddha's peaceful presence among all forms of plant life. The compound is a bahubbīhi meaning "having two leaves", formed from dvi "two" and paṇṇa "leaf".
34418.example_1:
na hi nūnimassa samaṇassa,
tilākhettasmi pāpakā,
ekapaṇṇā dupaṇṇā [dvipaṇṇā] ca,
tenāyaṃ samaṇo sukhī.

30954.grammar: masc loc sg of tucchakoṭṭha, comp, irreg
30954.meaning_1: in an empty granary; in a vacant store-room
30954.construction:
tuccha + koṭṭha + smiṃ > smi
tucchakoṭṭha + smi
30954.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The form tucchakoṭṭhasmi is an irregular locative singular of the compound tucchakoṭṭha "empty granary". The ending -smi represents a contracted form of -asmiṃ, commonly found in Vedic and early Pāḷi. The contextual sentence "tucchakoṭṭhasmi mūsikā" literally means "rats in a vacant barn", illustrating the image of emptiness and desolation.

17238.meaning_1: a state of heat or warmth; fervor; ardor; especially in the context of dancing or celebration
17238.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.10:4.3, ussoḷhikāya naccanti means "they dance in a state of warmth/heat" or "they dance with fervor". This word describes a heated or enthusiastic state, often associated with passionate dancing or celebration. It is a feminine noun formed from the prefix ut- (intensive), soḷha (heat), and the suffix -ika, with the feminine ending -ā.

58350.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence sn7.10:5.2, "santhāro sattamāsiko" means "a carpet that (lasted) for seven months", indicating a floor covering or rug. This distinguishes it from santhāra 1, which means "welcome; reception; hospitality". Both derive from the same root but have specialized meanings.

57756.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word sattamāsika is an adjective meaning "for seven months" or "seven-month". In the contextual sentence "sn7.10:5.2: santhāro sattamāsiko" it modifies "carpets" indicating that the carpets last or are intended to be used for seven months. The compound is formed from satta (seven) and māsika (monthly), with the bahubbīhi structure indicating a duration of seven months.

16637.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word uppāṭaka refers to a flea, a small jumping insect. The contextual sentence "uppāṭakehi sañchanno" means "infested with fleas". The construction suggests "one who leaps upon" (upa + pāṭ + ka), referring to the flea's jumping nature.

33613.meaning_1: having two children; with two sons
33613.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word duputta is a compound meaning "having two children" or "with two sons". It appears in the context of a family description, contrasting with eka-putta "having one child". The construction is a typical Pāḷi digu (dvandva) compound formed from du "two" and putta "child, son". The meaning is literal and descriptive, used to specify family size.
33613.example_1: with one or two children each:

34425.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The form dviputtā in SN7.10 is a feminine singular nominative form of the adjective dviputta "with two sons". The context shows a contrast between a widow with seven daughters, a woman with one son (ekaputtā), and a woman with two sons (dviputtā), illustrating the Buddha's point that even a monk with minimal family attachments is happier than those burdened by many familial responsibilities.
34425.example_1:
na hi nūnimassa samaṇassa,
vidhavā satta dhītaro,
ekaputtā duputtā [dviputtā] ca,
tenāyaṃ samaṇo sukhī.

45979.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.10, piṅgala is used adjectivally to describe the skin color of a wife as "piṅgalā tilakāhatā", rendered as "a wife with sallow, blotchy skin". The term piṅgala refers to a tawny brown or reddish-yellow coloration, often used in Pāḷi literature to describe the color of animals (especially elephants), hair, or skin. The adjective agrees with the feminine noun in the sentence.
45979.example_1: a wife with sallow, blotchy skin

48694.meaning_1: causes to awaken; rouses; stirs up; incites
48694.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence sn7.10:7.3, bodheti is used in the sense of physically rousing someone from sleep by kicking them, showing the concrete causative meaning "to cause to wake up". The verb is a causative formation from bujjhati "to wake up, understand", formed with the causative suffix *e, and takes a direct object (trans +acc).
48694.example_1: to wake him with a kick:

13448.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word iṇāyika means "creditor" — one who has a claim to debt. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.10:8.2, "paccūsamhi iṇāyikā" describes creditors coming early in the morning to collect their dues, illustrating the social reality of debt and financial pressure in ancient Indian society. The formation shows a taddhita derivative using the suffix *ika added to a modified form of iṇa (debt), with phonetic changes following Pāṇinian rules (Kaccāyana 35, 34) where the vowel is lengthened and the semivowel y is inserted.

27212.meaning_1: (of a debt) pressures to repay; issues a demand
27212.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is codeti 2, a specialized meaning of codeti where it refers to a debt pressing for repayment or issuing a financial demand. The contextual sentence "detha dethāti codenti" shows the creditor demanding payment. This differs from codeti 1 which means "accuses; charges; blames" in a legal or moral sense. The same root √cud underlies both meanings - the basic idea of "pressing" or "urging" takes financial context here.

16420.meaning_1: the chapter on lay devotees; the section concerning upāsakas
16420.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the heading for the second chapter (dutiyo) of the Saṃyutta Nikāya, specifically the "upāsakavagga" or "chapter on lay devotees". The numeral "1" in the headword likely refers to its position within a larger structural division. The term "upāsaka" refers to a lay follower of Buddhism, and "vagga" means chapter or section. This vagga contains discourses related to the conduct, virtues, and attainments of lay devotees.

20774.meaning_1: the Kasi Bharadvaja sutta; a discourse addressed to the brahmin Kasi Bharadvaja
20774.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the name of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN7.11), specifically in the Brāhmaṇasaṃyutta. It records a dialogue between the Buddha and the brahmin Kasi Bharadvaja. The compound is formed by combining the name of the brahmin (Kasi Bharadvaja) with "sutta" (discourse). The sandhi between "sutta" and the following "1" in the manuscript tradition creates "suttaṃ" as the nominative singular form.

17523.meaning_1: name of a Brahman village in Magadha
17523.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
Ekanāḷā is a proper noun referring to a specific brahmin village (brāhmaṇagāma) located in the Magadha region, in the Southern Hills (dakkhiṇāgiri). The name literally means "one stem" or "one stalk", likely referring to a geographical特征 or a symbolic reference. The word is a feminine compound formed from eka ("one") and nāḷa ("stem, stalk, tube"), with the feminine ending -ā. It appears in the canonical text SN 7.11 as the location where the Buddha was staying.
17523.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu viharati dakkhiṇāgirismiṃ ekanāḷāyaṃ brāhmaṇagāme.
17523.example_1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans in the Southern Hills near the brahmin village of Ekanāḷa.

20773.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
kasibhāradvāja is a proper name referring to a Brahmin known as "Bhāradvāja the Farmer". The compound is formed from kasi "cultivation, farming" and bhāradvāja, a common Brahmin surname. In the contextual sentence from SN7.11, he is described as owning five hundred plows during the sowing season, indicating his wealth and status as an agricultural landowner. The compound type is kammadhāraya, where kasi functions adjectivally to qualify bhāradvāja.
20773.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa pañcamattāni naṅgalasatāni payuttāni honti vappakāle.
20773.example_1: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer had harnessed around five hundred plows, it being the season for sowing.

20754.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the name of a Brahman farmer mentioned in SN7.11. The variant kasibhāradvāja (id 20773) appears in the same passage in brackets, showing the textual variation between kasika- and kasi-. The compound means "farmer Bhāradvāja" and refers to a specific individual in the Brāhmaṇasaṃyutta.
20754.example_1: evaṃ me sutaṃ, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu viharati dakkhiṇāgirismiṃ ekanāḷāyaṃ brāhmaṇagāme. tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa [kasikabhāradvājassa] brāhmaṇassa pañcamattāni naṅgalasatāni payuttāni honti vappakāle. atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa kammanto tenupasaṅkami.

35446.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This compound means "one hundred ploughs" and is used in the context of agriculture. In the given sentence from SN 7.11, it describes the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer having five hundred ploughs harnessed for the sowing season, indicating his great wealth and agricultural productivity. The compound follows the standard Pāḷi pattern for hundreds (sata) combined with the noun naṅgala (plough).
35446.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa pañcamattāni naṅgalasatāni payuttāni honti vappakāle.
35446.example_1: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer had harnessed around five hundred plows, it being the season for sowing.

54220.meaning_1: carrying to sanctuary; transporting to release from the yoke
54220.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word yogakkhemādhivāhana means "carrying to sanctuary" or "transporting to release from the yoke." In the context of SN 7.11:6.2, it expresses the idea of being conveyed from bondage (yoga) to safety or liberation (khema). The compound combines yogakkhema ("release from the yoke" or "safety") with ādhivāhana ("carrying, bearing, transporting"). This reflects a soteriological theme common in early Buddhist literature, where spiritual practice is seen as a movement from suffering to liberation.
54220.example_1: transporting me to sanctuary from the yoke.

14985.meaning_1: the Udaya Sutta; a discourse addressed to Udaya
14985.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The udayasutta is the 12th sutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya's 7th Saṃyutta (Brāhmaṇasaṃyutta). It records a dialogue between the Buddha and the brahmin Udaya, addressing questions about the nature of the holy life and the path to liberation.

38959.meaning_1: annoying; irritating; troublesome; disturbing; (comm) greedy for taste
38959.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word pakaṭṭhaka is used in SN 7.12:1.6 to express irritation toward the repeated visits of the ascetic Gotama. The speaker finds his constant coming back annoying and troublesome. The meaning "greedy for taste" from commentaries may reflect a metaphorical extension of the idea of being "hard to digest" or "unpleasant to take in", much like an irritating presence.
38959.example_1: “This ascetic Gotama is such a drag! He keeps coming back again and again!”

34530.meaning_1: acquires grain; obtains grain; gets grain
34530.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The verb dhaññamupeti means "acquires grain" or "obtains grain." In the contextual sentence from SN 7.12:2.4, punappunaṃ dhaññamupeti raṭṭhaṃ, it is used in the passive sense: "grain is produced/obtained again and again for the nation." This reflects the agricultural abundance and prosperity of the country. The compound is formed from dhaññaṃ (grain, rice, crops) + upeti (approaches, acquires), with the sandhi change ṃu > mu. It belongs to a productive class of Pāḷi compound verbs ending in -upeti, indicating attainment or approach to the object.
34530.example_1: again and again, grain is produced for the nation.

53920.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The headword yācayati is the causative form of yācati, meaning "to cause to ask" or "to solicit". In the given sentence "punappunaṃ yācakā yācayanti", it describes the action of beggars repeatedly begging, emphasizing the intentional solicitation of alms or requests. The Sanskrit field was corrected to show the proper causative form rather than just the root notation.
53920.example_1: Again and again, the beggars beg;

23796.meaning_1: pertaining to milk; milky; producing milk
23796.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word khīranika in the context of SN 7.12 describes dairy farmers (punappunaṃ khīranikā duhanti) who repeatedly milk cows. It is an adjective formed from khīra (milk) with the suffix -nika, indicating association or relation. Thus, khīranika means "pertaining to milk" or "engaged in milking." The form khīranikā is the nominative plural, referring to a group of milkers or dairy workers.
23796.example_1: Again and again, dairy farmers milk;

33868.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
duhati is a present tense verb meaning "milks" or "draws milk from". It is used transitively with the accusative case (+acc). The contextual sentence from SN 7.12:4.1 shows dairy farmers repeatedly milking: "punappunaṃ khīranikā duhanti" - "Again and again, dairy farmers milk." The root is √duh, and the verb is formed by adding the present tense suffix -ati to the strengthened root form duha.
33868.example_1: Again and again, dairy farmers milk;

24392.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
gabbhamupeti is a compound verb meaning "gets reborn", literally "approaches a womb". In the contextual sentence (sn7.12:4.4), it describes a dullard who repeatedly returns to the womb, illustrating the cycle of rebirth. The phonetic change ṃu > mu is a regular sandhi development in Pāḷi compound verbs formed with upeti.
24392.example_1: that dullard returns to the womb again and again.

34144.meaning_1: the Devahita Sutta; a discourse on what is beneficial for deities
34144.meaning_lit: sutta on what is beneficial for gods
34144.compound_construction: devassa hitāya hoti iti devahitaṃ + sutta
34144.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is a kammadhāraya compound meaning "a sutta on what is beneficial for deities." Found in SN 7.13, it belongs to the Saṃyutta Nikāya section dealing with deities (devasaṃyutta). The compound combines deva ("deity") + hita ("beneficial") + sutta ("discourse").

66775.meaning_1: suffering from gas; ill with gastritis
66775.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term vātehābādhika describes someone afflicted by wind or gas, as seen in SN 7.13 where the Buddha is said to be suffering from this condition. It is a bahubbīhi compound meaning "one who is oppressed by wind" (vātehi ābādhito). The literal meaning "oppressed by wind" reflects the ancient understanding of digestive disorders as caused by imbalanced bodily winds (vāta).
66775.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena bhagavā vātehābādhiko hoti;
66775.example_1: Now at that time the Buddha was afflicted by winds.

34143.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
Devahita is a compound name meaning "benefactor of the gods" (devassa hita), functioning as a personal name for a Brahmin in the text. The compound is a chaṭṭhī tappurisa (genitive determinative), where devassa "of the gods" qualifies hita "welfare, benefit". The contextual sentence shows Upavāna the monk visiting the Brahmin Devahita's home, indicating this is a proper name used in narrative context.
34143.sutta_1: “evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā upavāṇo bhagavato paṭissutvā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena devahitassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tuṇhībhūto ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
34143.example_1: “Yes, sir,” replied Upavāna. He robed up, and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the brahmin Devahita, and stood silently to one side.

53930.meaning_1: come to ask; arrived to beg (for)
53930.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The compound yācitumāgata literally means "come to ask" or "arrived to beg". It is formed from yācituṃ (infinitive of yācati "to ask, beg") and āgata "come, arrived". The sandhi change ṃā > mā is regular. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.13, it is used by the Buddha to question a brahmin who has come to ask for something, showing the idiomatic usage of this compound to describe someone who has come with a request.
53930.example_1: What have you come here to ask for?”

47157.meaning_1: worthy of veneration; reverable; deserving honour
47157.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the context of SN 7.13:4.1, pūjaneyya is used as a noun meaning "the one who is worthy of veneration" or "the venerable one". The sentence "pūjito pūjaneyyānaṃ" suggests someone who has been honoured among those who are worthy of honour, highlighting a hierarchy of reverence.
47157.example_1: I wish to bring it to the one

56419.grammar: ptp, masc dat pl of sakkareyya, comp vb, irreg
56419.meaning_1: to those worthy of honour; for those deserving respect
56419.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The form sakkareyyāna is the masculine dative plural of the potential participle sakkareyya, meaning "to be honoured" or "worthy of honour". It is an irregular formation from the compound verb sakkaroti (to honour). In the context of SN 7.13:4.2, it functions as the dative of reference, indicating "to those who are worthy of honour" or "for those deserving respect". The construction shows the typical Pāḷi pattern where sat (good, worthy) combines with kareyya (to be done, should be made) to form a compound meaning "should be honoured".
56419.example_1: who is esteemed by the estimable,

6086.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The form apaceyya is a future passive participle (gerundival suffix -eyya) from the root √cāy with prefix apa, meaning "to be honoured" or "worthy of honour". In the contextual sentence "apacito apaceyyānaṃ" it means "honored by the honorable" – i.e., one who is worthy of honour. It is an adjective in the plural genitive or instrumental case, agreeing with a plural noun meaning "the honorable ones".

6083.meaning_1: worthy of disrespect; deserving to be looked down upon; fit to be despised
6083.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word apacineyya appears in SN7.13 in a context contrasting honor and disrespect. The sentence structure shows a parallel: "pūjito pūjaneyyānaṃ, sakkareyyāna sakkato, apacito apaceyyānaṃ" — meaning someone honored by those worthy of honor, respected by those who should be respected, but disrespected by those who should be disrespected. The form apacineyya is a passive participle meaning "worthy of being looked down upon" or "deserving disrespect". It is formed with the negative prefix a- added to paciniyya (from √pac -> paceti, meaning to honor or respect). The variant reading apacineyyānaṃ in the commentary suggests this form was recognized as grammatically valid. The word illustrates ethical reciprocity in Buddhist thought — how one is treated reflects both the moral quality of the person and the appropriateness of the treatment.
6083.example_1:
pūjito pūjaneyyānaṃ,
sakkareyyāna sakkato,
apacito apaceyyānaṃ [apacineyyānaṃ ṭīkā oloketabbā],
tassa icchāmi hātaveti.

71137.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The infinitive hātave means "to bring" or "to fetch" and is used in SN 7.13:4.4 with the accusative case. It is an irregular formation from √har with the change ar > ā and the infinitive suffix -tave. The context shows someone expressing a desire to bring something, likely in a ritual or offering context.

35983.meaning_1: having caused to bathe; having washed (someone)
35983.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In SN7.13, āyasmā Upavāṇa uses hot water to bathe the Buddha, i.e., he causes the Buddha to be bathed. The absolutive nahāpetvā indicates the action of giving a bath to another person, reflecting the causative nature of the root verb nahāpeti. This aligns with the contextual meaning of "having caused to bathe" or "having washed (someone)" rather than simply "having bathed" (which would be nhātvā from nhāyati).
35983.example_1: atha kho devahito brāhmaṇo uṇhodakassa kājaṃ purisena gāhāpetvā phāṇitassa ca puṭaṃ āyasmato upavāṇassa pādāsi. atha kho āyasmā upavāṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ uṇhodakena nhāpetvā [nahāpetvā] uṇhodakena phāṇitaṃ āloletvā bhagavato pādāsi. atha kho bhagavato ābādho paṭippassambhi.

12724.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.13, āloletvā describes the action of stirring molasses (phāṇita) into hot water before offering it to the Buddha. The term emphasizes the completed action of mixing or agitating one substance into another, specifically in a preparation context.
12724.sutta_1: atha kho āyasmā upavāṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ uṇhodakena nhāpetvā uṇhodakena phāṇitaṃ āloletvā bhagavato pādāsi.
12724.example_1: Then Venerable Upavāna went up to the Buddha and bathed him with the hot water. Then he stirred molasses into hot water and presented it to the Buddha.

51964.meaning_1: the Great Householder Sutta; a discourse addressed to a great householder
51964.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
mahāsālasutta is the 14th sutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya 7 (Brāhmaṇasaṃyutta). It is a discourse addressed to a great householder (mahāsāla), explaining the Dhamma in the context of household life. The compound is a kammadhāraya where mahāsāla (great householder) qualifies the noun sutta (discourse).

55921.meaning_1: wearing a rough cloak; dressed in a shabby overgarment
55921.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term lūkhapāvuraṇa describes someone who wears a rough or shabby cloak. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.14, it characterizes a well-to-do brahmin who has adopted an outward appearance of simplicity or austerity, wearing coarse garments despite his social status. This reflects the ascetic aesthetic common in renunciant traditions, where rough clothing symbolizes detachment from luxury.
55921.sutta_1: atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇamahāsālo lūkho lūkhapāvuraṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
55921.example_1: Then a certain well-to-do brahmin, shabby, wearing a shabby cloak, went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

55920.meaning_1: wearing a rough cloak; dressed in a shabby overgarment
55920.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word lūkhapāpuraṇa appears in SN7.14 describing a Brahmin who approaches the Buddha wearing rough or shabby clothing, symbolizing ascetic practice. The variant lūkhapāvuraṇo in the text is a scribal variation. The term combines lūkha "rough, coarse" with pāpuraṇa "cloak, covering", forming a kammadhāraya compound meaning "one who wears a rough cloak". This reflects the ascetic ideal of simplicity in early Buddhist literature.
55920.example_1: sāvatthinidānaṃ. atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇamahāsālo lūkho lūkhapāvuraṇo  [lūkhapāpuraṇo] yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.

61623.meaning_1: at the request; at the behest (of)
61623.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In SN7.14, the gerund saṃpuccha is used with the instrumental case dārehi (wives) to indicate that the sons left the house at the request or behest of their wives. The construction dārehi saṃpuccha literally means "asked by the wives" or "at the asking of the wives", conveying the idea of acting upon someone's request or instruction.
61623.example_1: idha me, bho gotama, cattāro puttā. te maṃ dārehi saṃpuccha gharā nikkhāmentīti. tena hi tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, imā gāthāyo pariyāpuṇitvā sabhāyaṃ mahājanakāye sannipatite puttesu ca sannisinnesu bhāsassu –

36790.meaning_1: drives out; expels; ejects; evacuates; excretes
36790.phonetic:
īk > ikkh
k > kh (Kacc 20, 27)
a > ā
36790.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.14:1.6, "te maṃ dārehi sampuccha gharā nikkhāmentī"ti", nikkhāmeti is used in the sense of "expels" or "drives out" — specifically, the speaker is saying "at their wives' bidding they expelled me from my house." This reflects the causative nature of the verb, causing someone to go out from a place. The dual case government (+acc & +abl) is evident: the person being expelled (accusative) and the place they are expelled from (ablative).
36790.sutta_1: te maṃ dārehi sampuccha gharā nikkhāmentī”ti.
36790.example_1: At their wives’ bidding they expelled me from my house.”

49572.meaning_1: wished for the well-being; desired the prosperity (of)
49572.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The form bhavamicchi is an aorist compound verb meaning "wished for the well-being" or "desired the prosperity" of someone. It occurs in SN 7.14:2.2 where it describes a benevolent wish directed toward others. The compound is formed from bhavaṃ (well-being, prosperity) and icchi (wish, desire), with the sandhi change ṃi > mi. This reflects a compassionate intention rather than a selfish desire.

9429.grammar: adj, from prp of na atthi
9429.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.14:3.1, "asantā kira maṃ jammā" translates to "It turns out they're wicked, those nasty men." Here, asanta is used in the plural nominative form (asantā) to describe people who are morally bad or unvirtuous. The literal meaning "not existing" has evolved metaphorically to mean "wicked" or "bad" in ethical context, reflecting the Pāḷi worldview where virtue is associated with true existence and goodness, while vice is seen as a form of non-existence or spiritual death.
9429.example_1: It turns out they’re wicked, those nasty men,

46649.grammar: ind, adv, comp, instr sg of puttarūpa
46649.meaning_1: in the form of sons; with the appearance of sons
46649.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In SN 7.14:3.3, "rakkhasā puttarūpena" describes demons or malevolent beings who appear in the guise of sons, suggesting a deceptive or threatening form. The instrumental case ending -ena indicates manner or means, thus "in the form of sons" or "with the appearance of sons." This reflects a common Pāḷi literary device where supernatural beings take familiar human forms to mislead or harm.
46649.example_1: They’re monsters in the shape of sons,

66340.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
vayogata means "grown old" or "reached old age". The contextual sentence from SN 7.14 shows someone being cast aside due to old age: "te jahanti vayogataṃ" = "they abandon him as he has grown old". The compound is formed from vayo (age) + gata (gone), literally "gone to age".
66340.example_1: throwing me out as I’ve grown old.

24738.meaning_1: gets a foothold; finds a footing
24738.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The verb gādhamedhati means "to get a foothold" or "to find a footing", used literally in the sense of finding stable ground, especially in deep or difficult conditions. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.14:6.2, "gambhīre gādhamedhati" means "in deep waters it finds a footing", suggesting stability or security even in challenging circumstances. The compound is formed from gādhaṃ (a foothold, foundation) and edhati (to thrive, grow, gain strength), with the phonetic change ṃe > me due to sandhi.
24738.example_1: in deep waters it finds a footing.

23579.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
khalitvā is the absolutive (gerund) form of khalati "to stumble, trip". In the contextual sentence from SN7.14:6.4, it expresses the idea of "having stumbled" and is followed by patitiṭṭhati "I stand firm", conveying the moral that even when one stumbles in life, one can regain stability. The absolutive here indicates a prior action that sets the stage for the main verb.
23579.example_1: when I stumble, I stand firm again.’”

41802.meaning_1: stands firm again; recovers; regains footing
41802.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The verb patitiṭṭhati means "to stand back" or "to stand firm again" after stumbling or falling. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.14:6.4, "khalitvā patitiṭṭhatī'ti", it conveys the sense of recovering one's footing or composure after a misstep. The prefix pati- intensifies the meaning of the root √ṭhā "to stand", giving the sense of standing firmly or resolutely.
41802.example_1: when I stumble, I stand firm again.’”

38766.meaning_1: having led; having taken; having guided
38766.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the context of SN7.14:13.1, netvā means "having led" or "having taken" and refers to the action of the brahmin's sons leading their father back home. The absolutive netvā expresses a prior action to the main verb, indicating the sequence: first they led him home, then they bathed and clothed him.
38766.sutta_1: atha kho naṃ brāhmaṇamahāsālaṃ puttā gharaṃ netvā nhāpetvā paccekaṃ dussayugena acchādesuṃ.
38766.example_1: Then the brahmin’s sons led him back home, bathed him, and each clothed him with a fine pair of garments.

52272.meaning_1: the discourse on gaining advantage; the sutta about gaining benefit
52272.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is SN 7.15, a discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya where the Buddha teaches about gaining spiritual advantage through proper conduct and understanding. The compound means "discourse on gaining advantage" where māna means "gain" or "advantage", attha means "benefit" or "purpose", dhā is a verbal element meaning "holding" or "establishing", and sutta means "discourse" or "thread".

36533.meaning_1: does not speak; does not say anything
36533.construction:
na + ā + lapa + ti
na + ālapati
36533.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This negative form expresses deliberate silence in response to another's silence, as seen in SN 7.15 where the speaker vows not to speak if Gotama does not speak first. The construction clearly shows the negation of ālapati through the addition of na-, maintaining the same transitive +accusative syntax.
36533.sutta_1: no ce maṃ samaṇo gotamo ālapissati, ahampi nālapissāmī”ti.
36533.example_1: But if he doesn’t speak, neither will I.”

36534.meaning_1: did not speak; did not say anything
36534.construction:
na + ā + lapa + i
na + ālapi
36534.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the negative aorist form of ālapati, meaning "did not speak" or "did not address". In the context of SN 7.15:1.11, it describes the Buddha's deliberate silence towards someone, indicating refusal to engage in conversation or address the person.
36534.example_1: But the Buddha didn’t speak to him.

39341.meaning_1: the Paccanīka Sutta; a discourse on the antidote
39341.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The Paccanīka Sutta (SN 7.16) is a discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya where the Buddha teaches the brahmin Jānussoṇi about the "antidote" (paccanīka) to defilements. The term paccanīka means "antidote, counteraction, opposite" and refers to the Dhamma practice that counteracts unwholesome states. The sutta emphasizes mindfulness and the cultivation of wholesome qualities as the remedy for mental impurities.

49228.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
bhaṇati 2 is a specialized sense of the verb bhaṇati meaning "to preach, recite, or chant sacred texts." In the contextual sentence from SN 7.16, the Buddha instructs a monk to "preach the Dhamma" (bhaṇa samaṇadhamman), using the causative sense of reciting or proclaiming religious teachings. This distinguishes it from bhaṇati 1, which has the general meaning "to speak, say, tell." The specialized meaning is confirmed by related forms like bhaññamāna 2 "being chanted; being preached" and bhāṇaka "reciter; chanter of scriptures."

15372.meaning_1: with a defiled mind; mentally corrupt
15372.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word upakkiliṭṭhacitta means "with a defiled mind" or "mentally corrupt". It is a compound formed from upakkiliṭṭha (defiled, tainted) and citta (mind, consciousness). In the contextual sentence from SN 7.16:2.3, it describes someone whose mind is tainted or morally impure. The compound functions as an adjective describing a mental state characterized by defilement or moral corruption.

62495.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word sārambhabahula describes a state of being full of aggression or hostility. In the context of SN 7.16:2.4, it modifies a noun (likely a person or being) that is characterized by a belligerent or quarrelsome nature. The component sārambha refers to strife, conflict, or aggression, while bahula means "full of" or "abounding in". This compound is used to emphasize a strong tendency towards conflict or hostility.

35902.meaning_1: Sutta about the young carpenter; discourse addressed to a young carpenter
35902.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is SN 7.17, a discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya where the Buddha teaches a young carpenter (navakammika) about the nature of suffering and the path to liberation. The term "navakammika" means "young carpenter" (nava = new/young, kammika = worker/carpenter), and "sutta" refers to the discourse itself.

35901.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is a compound name referring to a Brahmin known as "Bhāradvāja the Builder" or "Bhāradvāja associated with new work/construction." The first element "navakammika" means "related to new work or building" (nava = new, kamma = work), and "bhāradvāja" is a common Brahmin family name. The contextual sentence from SN7.17 shows he was having building work done in a jungle thicket, confirming the meaning "Builder Bhāradvāja."
35901.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena navakammikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe kammantaṃ kārāpeti.
35901.example_1: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Builder was having some building work done in that jungle thicket.

62566.meaning_1: foot of a sal tree; base of a sal tree
62566.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.17, the Buddha is described as sitting at the foot of a sal tree (sālarukkhamūle), which is a locative singular form. This compound refers to the base or root area of a sal tree (Shorea robusta), a tree of great significance in Buddhist literature, often associated with important events such as the Buddha's birth and death. The construction shows a chaṭṭhī tappurisa (genitive) compound, literally meaning "root of the sal tree."
62566.sutta_1: addasā kho navakammikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ aññatarasmiṃ sālarukkhamūle nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
62566.example_1: He saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged at the root of a certain sal tree, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in his presence.

20469.meaning_1: there is something to be done (by); there is something to do
20469.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
karaṇīyamatthi is an impersonal compound verb meaning "there is something to be done" or "there is something to do". It is used in the negative in the text: "na me vanasmiṃ karaṇīyamatthi" — "There's nothing I need do in the jungle". The compound is formed from karaṇīyaṃ "to be done" + atthi "there is", with sandhi change ṃa > ma. It takes the instrumental case to indicate the agent by whom the action should be done.
20469.example_1: “There’s nothing I need do in the jungle;

19389.meaning_1: the wood-carrier discourse; the sutta about the wood carrier
19389.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the "Wood-Carrier Sutta" (SN 7.18), a discourse in the Brāhmaṇasaṃyutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya. The title literally means "wood-carrying discourse", referring to a bhikkhu who earns his living by carrying wood. The sutta deals with themes of contentment, simplicity, and the proper way of life for a bhikkhu, contrasting the humble wood-carrier with the lofty spiritual path.

24466.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
gambhīrarūpa is used in the sense of "deep" to describe the jungle (vana) as profound or unfathomable in its form, evoking a sense of mystery and danger. The compound combines gambhīra "deep" with rūpa "form, appearance" in a kammadhāraya (descriptive) compound, literally meaning "deep in form" and figuratively "profound, awesome in appearance".
24466.example_1: “Deep in the jungle so full of terrors,

67371.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The gerund vigāhiya appears in SN 7.18 describing one who has plunged into or deeply penetrated the empty, desolate wilderness. The form vigāhiya is an alternative to vigayha, both expressing the action of diving or plunging into something, often used metaphorically for deep engagement or immersion.
67371.example_1: you’ve plunged into the empty, desolate wilderness.

66221.meaning_1: resorted to the forest; living in the wood
66221.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The form vanavassita in the text is the nominative singular feminine agreeing with muni (which can be used as a feminine noun in poetic contexts) or more likely a typo/variant for vanavassito (masc. nom. sg.). The compound means "one who has resorted to the forest" or "forest-dweller", composed of vana "forest" and āvassita "resorted to, dwelling in". It describes a sage who has gone to live in the wilderness, a common theme in early Buddhist literature symbolizing renunciation and meditation.
66221.example_1: a lonely sage resorts to the wilderness.

1114.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word accherarūpa appears in SN 7.18:3.3 as accherarūpaṃ paṭibhāti maṃ idaṃ, meaning "This strikes me as an amazing thing." The compound is formed from acchera (marvellous, wonderful) and rūpa (form, appearance), literally meaning "marvellous form" or "wonderful in nature." It is used to express astonishment at something extraordinary or miraculous.
1114.example_1: This strikes me as an amazing thing,

56035.meaning_1: fellowship with the ruler of the world; company of god almighty
56035.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word lokādhipatisahabyatā means "fellowship with the ruler of the world" or "company of God almighty." It is a feminine compound noun formed from lokādhipati ("ruler of the world, God") and sahabyatā ("companionship, fellowship"). In the context of SN 7.18:4.1, it refers to the desire to be reborn in the company of the divine ruler, indicating a spiritual or devotional aspiration.
56035.example_1: I suppose you wish to be reborn in the company

67545.meaning_1: resorting to uninhabited forest; living in desolate jungle
67545.compound_construction: vijanaṃ araññaṃ assito ti, vijanaṃ + araññaṃ + āśrita
67545.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term vijanamaraññamassita describes a person who has taken up residence in a remote, uninhabited forest. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.18, it refers to a contemplative or ascetic who lives in solitude in the wilderness, likely for meditation or spiritual practice. The word is a compound formed from vijanaṃ (uninhabited, desolate), araññaṃ (forest, wilderness), and āśrita (resorted to, dependent on). The phonetic change ṃa > ma is a common sandhi feature in Pāḷi compounds.
67545.example_1: Is that why you resort to the desolate wilderness,

57952.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.18:5.2, "anekadhātūsu puthū sadāsitā", the word sadāsita describes a state of being always attached or ever dependent upon the many and various realms. It conveys a sense of continuous clinging or attachment to diverse states of existence, indicating a lack of liberation from samsaric conditions.
57952.example_1: to the many and various realms—

1614.meaning_1: born from the root of ignorance; sprung from the source of not knowing
1614.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This compound describes mental formations (pajappitā) that arise dependent on ignorance (aññāṇa) as their foundational cause. The contextual sentence from SN 7.18 illustrates how yearnings or cravings originate from this root of unknowing, emphasizing the Buddhist teaching that ignorance is the primary condition for the arising of suffering.
1614.example_1: the yearnings sprung from the root of unknowing—

48748.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word byantikata means "ended; eliminated; stopped" and is used in SN 7.18:5.4 to express complete eradication "down to the root". It is a kammadhāraya compound formed from byanta ("ended, finished") and kata ("made, done"). The v > b phonetic change is regular in Pāḷi. The contextual sentence shows it used in the sense of completely eliminating defilements or problems at their root cause.
48748.example_1: I’ve eliminated them all down to the root.

69302.meaning_1: having clear vision; seeing clearly; (comm) having omniscient knowledge (of)
69302.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the context of SN 7.18:6.2, "sabbesu dhammesu visuddhadassano" means "amongst all things, my vision is clear." This describes a state of purified, unobstructed insight or understanding, often associated with the Buddha's omniscient knowledge. The compound is a kammadhāraya where "visuddha" (pure, clear) qualifies "dassana" (vision, seeing), literally meaning "clear-seeing" or "pure vision."
69302.example_1: amongst all things, my vision is clear.

52237.meaning_1: the Mother-Follower Discourse; a discourse about one who follows or serves their mother
52237.compound_construction: mātāya ahaṃ posako ti suttaṃ yatra tat
52237.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is SN 7.19, the "Mother-Follower Discourse" in the Saṃyutta Nikāya. The title refers to a discourse about a person (posaka) who follows or serves their mother (mātā). The compound is a kammadhāraya where "mātā" (mother) qualifies "posaka" (follower, servant), and together they modify "sutta" (discourse). The text likely deals with themes of filial duty, gratitude, and proper conduct toward one's mother.

52234.meaning_1: supporting one's mother; providing for one's mother
52234.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word mātuposaka refers to someone who supports or provides for their mother. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.19, it describes a brahmin who cares for his mother, indicating filial piety. The compound is formed from mātar (mother) and posaka (supporting, nourishing), functioning as an adjective describing a person's character or role.
52234.sutta_1: atha kho mātuposako brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
52234.example_1: Then a brahmin who provided for his mother went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

49861.meaning_1: the Bhikkhaka Sutta; a discourse on begging
49861.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term bhikkhakasutta refers to a specific sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN7.20) within the Brāhmaṇasaṃyutta. The compound is formed from bhikkhaka ("begging" or "a beggar") and suttā ("discourse" or "sutta"). It is a kammadhāraya compound where the first member qualifies the second, indicating a discourse concerning begging or addressed to beggars. The Sanskrit equivalent shows the same components: bhikṣaka (beggar) + sūkta/sūtra (discourse).

56961.meaning_1: the Saṅgārava Sutta; the discourse addressed to Saṅgārava the brahmin
56961.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is SN 7.21, the discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya where the Buddha teaches the brahmin Saṅgārava about the true nature of purification, emphasizing that it is not achieved through ritual bathing in rivers but through ethical conduct and mental purification. The title literally means "the sutta (discourse) concerning Saṅgārava."

14896.meaning_1: purified by water; relating to water purification
14896.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term udakasuddhika refers to one who is purified by water or who practices purification through water. In the context of SN 7.21, it describes a brahmin who is devoted to ritual purification by immersing himself in water at dawn and dusk, reflecting a pre-Buddhist ascetic practice.
14896.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena saṅgāravo nāma brāhmaṇo sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasati udakasuddhiko, udakena parisuddhiṃ pacceti, sāyaṃ pātaṃ udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
14896.example_1: Now at that time there was a brahmin named Saṅgārava staying in Sāvatthī. He practiced purification by water, believing in purification by water. He lived committed to the practice of immersing himself in water at dawn and dusk.

14894.meaning_1: water purification; ritual purification by water
14894.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.21, the Buddha questions a brahmin about his practice of "udakasuddhi", which refers to ritual purification by water. This term denotes the act or practice of purifying oneself through water, a common ritual practice in ancient Indian religions. The compound consists of "udaka" (water) and "suddhi" (purity/purification), formed as a kammadhāraya compound where the first member qualifies the second.
14894.sutta_1: “kiṃ pana tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno udakasuddhiko, udakasuddhiṃ paccesi, sāyaṃ pātaṃ udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharasī”ti?
14894.example_1: “But brahmin, for what reason do you practice purification by water?”

38923.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.21, the word nhāna refers to ritual bathing as a means of purification. The speaker explains that they wash away bad deeds committed during the day by bathing at dusk, and those committed at night by bathing at dawn. This reflects the ancient Indian belief in the purificatory power of water, where physical bathing symbolizes moral and spiritual cleansing. The term is neuter gender and functions as a verbal noun (action noun) derived from the root √nhā meaning "to bathe".
38923.sutta_1: “idha me, bho gotama, yaṃ divā pāpakammaṃ kataṃ hoti, taṃ sāyaṃ nhānena pavāhemi, yaṃ rattiṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ hoti taṃ pātaṃ nhānena pavāhemi.
38923.example_1: “It’s because, worthy Gotama, whatever bad deeds I’ve done during the day I wash off by bathing at dusk; and whatever bad deeds I’ve done during the night, I wash off by bathing at dawn.

23977.meaning_1: the Khomadussa Sutta; the discourse about the dust and dirt
23977.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the name of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 7.22), known as the Khomadussa Sutta. The title is a kammadhāraya compound meaning "dust-dirt discourse" or "the discourse about dust and dirt", likely referring to the metaphorical use of dust and dirt to illustrate spiritual defilements.

23975.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This entry represents the toponymic use of khomadussa, referring to a village in the Sakyan territory where the Buddha stayed. The word is etymologically derived from "khoma" (flax) and "dussa" (cloth), literally meaning "flax cloth", but in this context it functions as a place name. The compound type is kammadhāraya, indicating that the village is characterized by or associated with flax cloth production. The contextual sentence from SN 7.22 confirms this as a geographical location within the Sakyan realm.
23975.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati khomadussaṃ nāmaṃ sakyānaṃ nigamo.
23975.example_1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, where they have a town named Khomadussa.

23976.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word khomadussaka is a taddhita derivative formed by adding the suffix -ka to khomadussa, indicating belonging or origin. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.22, it refers to the brahmins and householders who are from the village of Khomadussa. The meaning "from Khomadussa; living in Khomadussa" is clearly supported by the context where people from this place are gathered in the council hall.
23976.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena khomadussakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā sabhāyaṃ sannipatitā honti kenacideva karaṇīyena, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyati.
23976.example_1: Now at that time the brahmins and householders of Khomadussa were gathered in the council hall for some business, while a gentle rain drizzled down.

59088.meaning_1: council rules; protocols of the assembly
59088.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term sabhādhamma refers to the established rules or protocols governing conduct within a council or assembly. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.22, the speaker questions whether certain ascetics understand these council rules, implying they are acting improperly or without proper knowledge of communal discipline. The compound is formed from sabhā ("assembly, council") and dhamma ("law, rule, principle"), functioning as a kammadhāraya (determinative) compound where sabhā qualifies dhamma.
59088.sutta_1: “ke ca muṇḍakā samaṇakā, ke ca sabhādhammaṃ jānissantī”ti?
59088.example_1: “Who are these shavelings, these fake ascetics? Don’t they understand the council rules?”

36764.meaning_1: the sutta that has gone forth; the discourse that has been delivered
36764.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term nikkhantasuttaṃ in SN8.1 refers to a specific discourse in the Vaṅgīsasaṃyutta. The compound means "the sutta that has gone forth" or "the discourse that has been delivered," with nikkhanta meaning "gone forth, departed, delivered" and sutta meaning "discourse, thread." This appears to be the title of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya collection.

31836.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
daditvā is the absolutive form of dadāti "to give, offer, donate". In the contextual sentence from SN 7.12:3.3, it functions as a temporal clause meaning "when the donors have given" or "after giving", indicating the action of giving that precedes the main verb. The form is irregular, built from the reduplicated present stem dadā + itvā, rather than the expected datvā from the root √dā + tvā.
31836.example_1: Again and again, when the donors have given,

39682.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The contextual sentence aññāṇamūlappabhavā pajappitā, "the yearnings sprung from the root of unknowing," illustrates pajappita as a neuter abstract noun meaning "yearning" or "desire" that arises from ignorance. It refers to the mental formations or cravings that stem from delusion, a key concept in Buddhist teachings on the origin of suffering.
39682.example_1: the yearnings sprung from the root of unknowing—
